articles.headline: Scott Walker, Set for a Bigger Stage, Faces G.O.P. Revolt in Wisconsin
articles.snippet: Gov. Scott Walker has promised to bring what he called “big bold leadership” to Washington, as he did in Wisconsin, but he faces a cloud over that story line: Republicans back home are in revolt.
articles.abstract: Gov. Scott Walker has promised to bring what he called “big bold leadership” to Washington, as he did in Wisconsin, but he faces a cloud over that story line: Republicans back home are in revolt.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — As Gov. Scott Walker prepares to announce his campaign for president next month, promising to bring what he calls “big bold leadership” to Washington, as he did in Wisconsin, he faces a cloud over that story line: Republicans back home are in revolt.

articles.headline: Charleston Residents Seek Lasting Change From Moment of Unity
articles.snippet: What is clear to most in Charleston is that the issues that affect people’s lives, like access to good education, go far beyond what happens with a Confederate flag.
articles.abstract: What is clear to most in Charleston is that the issues that affect people’s lives, like access to good education, go far beyond what happens with a Confederate flag.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — From a wicker chair on the porch of her daisy yellow bungalow, Cheryl Lee panned from right to left, pointing to the houses on the block — the blue one, the brick one, the light green one — that had transitioned from black ownership to white.

articles.headline: Climate Change Calls for Science, Not Hope
articles.snippet: Many current proposals for reducing carbon emissions are driven by ideological or economic agendas.
articles.abstract: Many current proposals for reducing carbon emissions are driven by ideological or economic agendas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the American approach to combating climate change going off the rails?

articles.headline: Don Featherstone, Inventor of the Pink Flamingo (in Plastic), Dies at 79
articles.snippet: Mr. Featherstone’s first pink plastic flamingo came off the assembly line in 1957.
articles.abstract: Mr. Featherstone’s first pink plastic flamingo came off the assembly line in 1957.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don Featherstone did not invent Phoenicopterus ruber: Nature took care of that eons ago. But what Mr. Featherstone did nearly six decades ago — in the process indelibly altering the landscape of midcentury America — was to cast the creature in plastic and attach slender, rodlike legs for planting it in the ground.

articles.headline: As Greece Calms, Investors Find Other Concerns
articles.snippet: While avoiding a financial disaster in Europe would remove a pressing worry, investors still have plenty to worry about in this long bull market.
articles.abstract: While avoiding a financial disaster in Europe would remove a pressing worry, investors still have plenty to worry about in this long bull market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greed and fear are the primal forces that in the past have driven the stock market to its highs and lows. Now the dominant emotion among investors seems to be lukewarm enthusiasm.

articles.headline: More Americans Are Renting, and Paying More, as Homeownership Falls
articles.snippet: Millions of Americans are unwillingly stuck in rental housing, even as the housing market is starting to improve.
articles.abstract: Millions of Americans are unwillingly stuck in rental housing, even as the housing market is starting to improve.
articles.lead_paragraph: WESTFIELD, N.J. — To Johnnie McDowell, the house on Livingston Street seems to taunt him every time he walks by. It’s nothing special: The two-story home is a bit shabby, and it’s been on and off the market in recent months without finding a buyer. Still, he cannot stop dreaming of a better life for his family as he imagines the extra space inside and his children and dog playing outdoors once he weeds the yard.

articles.headline: Homegrown Extremists Tied to Deadlier Toll Than Jihadists in U.S. Since 9/11
articles.snippet: A count by a research center found that non-Muslim extremists have been far more lethal than Islamic militants on American soil since Sept. 11, 2001, running counter to public perception.
articles.abstract: A count by a research center found that non-Muslim extremists have been far more lethal than Islamic militants on American soil since Sept. 11, 2001, running counter to public perception.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the 14 years since Al Qaeda carried out attacks on New York and the Pentagon, extremists have regularly executed smaller lethal assaults in the United States, explaining their motives in online manifestoes or social media rants.

articles.headline: Ahold-Delhaize Deal Would Create One of Largest Grocery Chains in U.S.
articles.snippet: The all-share deal would combine Delhaize, the owner of the American brand Food Lion, with Ahold, which owns the Stop & Shop and Giant chains.
articles.abstract: The all-share deal would combine Delhaize, the owner of the American brand Food Lion, with Ahold, which owns the Stop & Shop and Giant chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: The merger agreement between the Dutch supermarket operator Ahold and the Delhaize Group of Belgium on Wednesday reflected yet another sign of the malaise hanging over the grocery business in the United States.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Start-Ups Finding the Best Employees Are Actually Employed
articles.snippet: Some on-demand companies are rejecting the practice of using independent contractors, like Uber drivers, and are hiring people they can train and hold accountable.
articles.abstract: Some on-demand companies are rejecting the practice of using independent contractors, like Uber drivers, and are hiring people they can train and hold accountable.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ron Johnson was pitching his idea for an e-commerce delivery company to venture capitalists last year, one of the sticking points was his vision for how to treat employees.
